+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.

@@ -0,0 +1,197 @@
+=================
+Iceberg Connector
+=================
+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.
+The Iceberg connector allows querying data stored in
+files written in Iceberg format, as defined in the
+`Iceberg Table Spec <https://iceberg.apache.org/spec/>`_.
+
+The Iceberg connector supports:
+
+* All Presto types, including TIME, TIMESTAMP, DECIMAL
+* CREATE TABLE and CREATE TABLE AS
+* Partitioning tables by any Presto type
+* Dropping tables
+* Renaming tables
+* Deletion by partition
+* Table and column statistics
+* Table and column comments
+* Rolling back a table to a previous state
+* Schema evolution
+
+The Iceberg table state is maintained in metadata files. All changes to table state
+create a new metadata file and replace the old metadata with an atomic swap.
+The table metadata file tracks the table schema, partitioning config,
+custom properties, and snapshots of the table contents.
+
+Iceberg data files can be stored in either Parquet or ORC format, as
+determined by the ``format`` property in the table definition.  The
+table ``format`` defaults to ``ORC``.
+
+Iceberg is designed to improve on the known scalabilty limitations of Hive.  Hive
+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.
+
+Status
+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.

@@ -0,0 +1,197 @@
+=================
+Iceberg Connector
+=================
+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.
+The Iceberg connector allows querying data stored in
+files written in Iceberg format, as defined in the
+`Iceberg Table Spec <https://iceberg.apache.org/spec/>`_.
+
+The Iceberg connector supports:
+
+* All Presto types, including TIME, TIMESTAMP, DECIMAL
+* CREATE TABLE and CREATE TABLE AS
+* Partitioning tables by any Presto type
+* Dropping tables
+* Renaming tables
+* Deletion by partition
+* Table and column statistics
+* Table and column comments
+* Rolling back a table to a previous state
+* Schema evolution
+
+The Iceberg table state is maintained in metadata files. All changes to table state
+create a new metadata file and replace the old metadata with an atomic swap.
+The table metadata file tracks the table schema, partitioning config,
+custom properties, and snapshots of the table contents.
+
+Iceberg data files can be stored in either Parquet or ORC format, as
+determined by the ``format`` property in the table definition.  The
+table ``format`` defaults to ``ORC``.
+
+Iceberg is designed to improve on the known scalabilty limitations of Hive.  Hive
+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.
+
+Status
+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.
+
+Compatibility With Spark Iceberg
+--------------------------------
+
+Tests have been written to demonstrate that data written by Presto can be read
+using Spark SQL with the Iceberg format, and vice versa.  See
+`TestSparkCompatibility <https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-product-tests/src/main/java/io/prestosql/tests/iceberg/TestSparkCompatibility.java>`_.
+
+Configuration
+-------------
+
+Iceberg supports the same metastore configuration properties as the Hive connector.
+At a minimum, ``hive.metastore.uri`` must be configured:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    connector.name=iceberg
+    hive.metastore.uri=thrift://localhost:9083
+
+Partitioned Tables
+------------------
+
+Iceberg supports partitioning by specifying transforms over the table columns.
+A partition is created for each unique tuple value produced by the transforms.
+Identity transforms are simply the column name. Other transforms are:
+
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+Transform                             Description
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+``year(ts)``                          The partition value is the integer difference in years between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.

+=================
+Iceberg Connector
+=================
+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.
+The Iceberg connector allows querying data stored in
+files written in Iceberg format, as defined in the
+`Iceberg Table Spec <https://iceberg.apache.org/spec/>`_.
+
+The Iceberg connector supports:
+
+* All Presto types, including TIME, TIMESTAMP, DECIMAL
+* CREATE TABLE and CREATE TABLE AS
+* Partitioning tables by any Presto type
+* Dropping tables
+* Renaming tables
+* Deletion by partition
+* Table and column statistics
+* Table and column comments
+* Rolling back a table to a previous state
+* Schema evolution
+
+The Iceberg table state is maintained in metadata files. All changes to table state
+create a new metadata file and replace the old metadata with an atomic swap.
+The table metadata file tracks the table schema, partitioning config,
+custom properties, and snapshots of the table contents.
+
+Iceberg data files can be stored in either Parquet or ORC format, as
+determined by the ``format`` property in the table definition.  The
+table ``format`` defaults to ``ORC``.
+
+Iceberg is designed to improve on the known scalabilty limitations of Hive.  Hive
+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.
+
+Status
+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.
+
+Compatibility With Spark Iceberg
+--------------------------------
+
+Tests have been written to demonstrate that data written by Presto can be read
+using Spark SQL with the Iceberg format, and vice versa.  See
+`TestSparkCompatibility <https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-product-tests/src/main/java/io/prestosql/tests/iceberg/TestSparkCompatibility.java>`_.
+
+Configuration
+-------------
+
+Iceberg supports the same metastore configuration properties as the Hive connector.
+At a minimum, ``hive.metastore.uri`` must be configured:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    connector.name=iceberg
+    hive.metastore.uri=thrift://localhost:9083
+
+Partitioned Tables
+------------------
+
+Iceberg supports partitioning by specifying transforms over the table columns.
+A partition is created for each unique tuple value produced by the transforms.
+Identity transforms are simply the column name. Other transforms are:
+
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+Transform                             Description
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+``year(ts)``                          The partition value is the integer difference in years between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``month(ts)``                         The partition value is the integer difference in months between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``day(ts)``                           The partition value is the integer difference in days between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``hour(ts)``                          The partition value is a TIMESTAMP rounded down to the nearest hour.
+
+``bucket(x, nbuckets)``               The partition value is an integer hash of ``x``, with a value between 0 and ``nbuckets - 1`` inclusive.
+
+``truncate(s, nchars)``               The partition value is the first ``nchars`` characters of VARCHAR ``s``.
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+
+In this example, the table is partitioned by month and by a hash of the account number::
+
+    CREATE TABLE iceberg.testdb.sample_partitioned (
+        order_date DATE,
+        account_number BIGINT,
+        customer VARCHAR)
+    WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['month(order_date)', 'bucket(account_number, 10)'])
+
+Deletion by Partition
+---------------------
+
+For partitioned tables, the Iceberg connector supports the deletion of entire
+partitions if the WHERE clause specifies an identity transform of a partition

+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.

+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.
+
+Compatibility With Spark Iceberg
+--------------------------------
+
+Tests have been written to demonstrate that data written by Presto can be read
+using Spark SQL with the Iceberg format, and vice versa.  See
+`TestSparkCompatibility <https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-product-tests/src/main/java/io/prestosql/tests/iceberg/TestSparkCompatibility.java>`_.
+
+Configuration
+-------------
+
+Iceberg supports the same metastore configuration properties as the Hive connector.
+At a minimum, ``hive.metastore.uri`` must be configured:
+

+
+    connector.name=iceberg
+    hive.metastore.uri=thrift://localhost:9083
+
+Partitioned Tables
+------------------
+
+Iceberg supports partitioning by specifying transforms over the table columns.
+A partition is created for each unique tuple value produced by the transforms.
+Identity transforms are simply the column name. Other transforms are:
+
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+Transform                             Description
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+``year(ts)``                          The partition value is the integer difference in years between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``month(ts)``                         The partition value is the integer difference in months between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``day(ts)``                           The partition value is the integer difference in days between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``hour(ts)``                          The partition value is a TIMESTAMP rounded down to the nearest hour.
+
+``bucket(x, nbuckets)``               The partition value is an integer hash of ``x``, with a value between 0 and ``nbuckets - 1`` inclusive.
+
+``truncate(s, nchars)``               The partition value is the first ``nchars`` characters of VARCHAR ``s``.
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+

+

+partitions if the WHERE clause specifies an identity transform of a partition
+column.  Given this table definition::

+        d double)

+    WHERE c = 1

+released.  When v2 is released, it will support row-level deletion and the
+Iceberg connector will be updated to provide row-level deletion.

+=================
+Iceberg Connector
+=================
+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.
+The Iceberg connector allows querying data stored in
+files written in Iceberg format, as defined in the
+`Iceberg Table Spec <https://iceberg.apache.org/spec/>`_.
+
+The Iceberg connector supports:
+
+* All Presto types, including TIME, TIMESTAMP, DECIMAL
+* CREATE TABLE and CREATE TABLE AS
+* Partitioning tables by any Presto type
+* Dropping tables
+* Renaming tables
+* Deletion by partition
+* Table and column statistics
+* Table and column comments
+* Rolling back a table to a previous state
+* Schema evolution
+
+The Iceberg table state is maintained in metadata files. All changes to table state
+create a new metadata file and replace the old metadata with an atomic swap.
+The table metadata file tracks the table schema, partitioning config,
+custom properties, and snapshots of the table contents.
+
+Iceberg data files can be stored in either Parquet or ORC format, as
+determined by the ``format`` property in the table definition.  The
+table ``format`` defaults to ``ORC``.
+
+Iceberg is designed to improve on the known scalabilty limitations of Hive.  Hive
+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.
+
+Status
+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.
+
+Compatibility With Spark Iceberg
+--------------------------------
+
+Tests have been written to demonstrate that data written by Presto can be read
+using Spark SQL with the Iceberg format, and vice versa.  See
+`TestSparkCompatibility <https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-product-tests/src/main/java/io/prestosql/tests/iceberg/TestSparkCompatibility.java>`_.
+
+Configuration
+-------------
+
+Iceberg supports the same metastore configuration properties as the Hive connector.
+At a minimum, ``hive.metastore.uri`` must be configured:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    connector.name=iceberg
+    hive.metastore.uri=thrift://localhost:9083
+
+Partitioned Tables
+------------------
+
+Iceberg supports partitioning by specifying transforms over the table columns.
+A partition is created for each unique tuple value produced by the transforms.
+Identity transforms are simply the column name. Other transforms are:
+
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+Transform                             Description
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+``year(ts)``                          The partition value is the integer difference in years between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``month(ts)``                         The partition value is the integer difference in months between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``day(ts)``                           The partition value is the integer difference in days between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``hour(ts)``                          The partition value is a TIMESTAMP rounded down to the nearest hour.
+
+``bucket(x, nbuckets)``               The partition value is an integer hash of ``x``, with a value between 0 and ``nbuckets - 1`` inclusive.
+
+``truncate(s, nchars)``               The partition value is the first ``nchars`` characters of VARCHAR ``s``.
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+
+In this example, the table is partitioned by month and by a hash of the account number::
+
+    CREATE TABLE iceberg.testdb.sample_partitioned (
+        order_date DATE,
+        account_number BIGINT,
+        customer VARCHAR)
+    WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['month(order_date)', 'bucket(account_number, 10)'])
+
+Deletion by Partition
+---------------------
+
+For partitioned tables, the Iceberg connector supports the deletion of entire
+partitions if the WHERE clause specifies an identity transform of a partition
+column.  Given this table definition::
+
+    CREATE TABLE test_partition_deletion (
+        c integer,
+        d double)
+        WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['c'])
+
+This SQL will delete all partitions for which c is 1::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1
+
+The current Iceberg connector is based on Iceberg v1.  Iceberg v2 is not yet
+released.  When v2 is released, it will support row-level deletion and the
+Iceberg connector will be updated to provide row-level deletion.
+
+The Iceberg connector currently supports only deletion by partition.
+This SQL below will fail because the doesn't span entire partitions::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1 AND d > 10
+
+Rolling Back to a Previous Snapshot
+-----------------------------------
+
+Iceberg supports a "snapshot" model of data, where table snapshots are
+identified by an ``long`` snapshot_ids.
+
+The connector provides a system snapshots table for each Iceberg table.  Snapshots are
+identified by BIGINT snapshot ids.  You can find the latest snapshot id for table
+foo by running the following command::
+

+At a minimum, ``hive.metastore.uri`` must be configured:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    connector.name=iceberg
+    hive.metastore.uri=thrift://localhost:9083
+
+Partitioned Tables
+------------------
+
+Iceberg supports partitioning by specifying transforms over the table columns.
+A partition is created for each unique tuple value produced by the transforms.
+Identity transforms are simply the column name. Other transforms are:
+
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+Transform                             Description
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+``year(ts)``                          The partition value is the integer difference in years between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``month(ts)``                         The partition value is the integer difference in months between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``day(ts)``                           The partition value is the integer difference in days between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``hour(ts)``                          The partition value is a TIMESTAMP rounded down to the nearest hour.
+
+``bucket(x, nbuckets)``               The partition value is an integer hash of ``x``, with a value between 0 and ``nbuckets - 1`` inclusive.
+
+``truncate(s, nchars)``               The partition value is the first ``nchars`` characters of VARCHAR ``s``.
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+
+In this example, the table is partitioned by month and by a hash of the account number::
+
+    CREATE TABLE iceberg.testdb.sample_partitioned (
+        order_date DATE,
+        account_number BIGINT,
+        customer VARCHAR)
+    WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['month(order_date)', 'bucket(account_number, 10)'])
+
+Deletion by Partition
+---------------------
+
+For partitioned tables, the Iceberg connector supports the deletion of entire
+partitions if the WHERE clause specifies an identity transform of a partition
+column.  Given this table definition::
+
+    CREATE TABLE test_partition_deletion (
+        c integer,
+        d double)
+        WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['c'])
+
+This SQL will delete all partitions for which c is 1::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1
+
+The current Iceberg connector is based on Iceberg v1.  Iceberg v2 is not yet
+released.  When v2 is released, it will support row-level deletion and the
+Iceberg connector will be updated to provide row-level deletion.
+
+The Iceberg connector currently supports only deletion by partition.
+This SQL below will fail because the doesn't span entire partitions::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1 AND d > 10
+
+Rolling Back to a Previous Snapshot
+-----------------------------------
+
+Iceberg supports a "snapshot" model of data, where table snapshots are
+identified by an ``long`` snapshot_ids.
+
+The connector provides a system snapshots table for each Iceberg table.  Snapshots are
+identified by BIGINT snapshot ids.  You can find the latest snapshot id for table
+foo by running the following command::
+
+    SELECT snapshot_id FROM 'foo$snapshots' ORDER BY committed_at DESC LIMIT 1
+
+A SQL procedure ``system.rollback_to_snapshot`` allows the caller to roll back
+the state of the table to a previous snapshot id::
+
+    CALL system.rollback_to_snapshot(schema_name, table_name, snapshot_id)
+
+Schema Evolution
+----------------
+
+Iceberg and the Iceberg connector support schema evolution, with safe
+column add, drop, reorder and rename operations, including in nested structures.
+Table partitioning can also be changed and the connector can still
+query data created before the partitioning change.
+
+Migrating Existing Tables
+-------------------------
+
+The connector can read from or write to Hive tables that have been migrated to Iceberg.
+Currently, there is no Presto support to migrate Hive tables to Presto, so you will
+need to use either the Iceberg API or Spark.
+
+System Tables and Columns
+-------------------------
+
+The connector supports ``table$partitions`` as a substitute for Hive's ``SHOW PARTITIONS``.
+The differences are that it returns some partition metrics for each partition value
+and you can also use it on unpartitioned tables.
+
+Iceberg supports ``$snapshot_id`` and ``$snapshot_timestamp_ms`` as hidden columns.

+=================

+* Table and column comments

+=================
+Iceberg Connector
+=================
+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.
+The Iceberg connector allows querying data stored in
+files written in Iceberg format, as defined in the
+`Iceberg Table Spec <https://iceberg.apache.org/spec/>`_.
+
+The Iceberg connector supports:
+
+* All Presto types, including TIME, TIMESTAMP, DECIMAL
+* CREATE TABLE and CREATE TABLE AS
+* Partitioning tables by any Presto type
+* Dropping tables
+* Renaming tables
+* Deletion by partition
+* Table and column statistics
+* Table and column comments
+* Rolling back a table to a previous state
+* Schema evolution
+
+The Iceberg table state is maintained in metadata files. All changes to table state
+create a new metadata file and replace the old metadata with an atomic swap.
+The table metadata file tracks the table schema, partitioning config,
+custom properties, and snapshots of the table contents.
+
+Iceberg data files can be stored in either Parquet or ORC format, as
+determined by the ``format`` property in the table definition.  The
+table ``format`` defaults to ``ORC``.
+
+Iceberg is designed to improve on the known scalabilty limitations of Hive.  Hive
+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.

+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.

+--------------------------------

+Tests have been written to demonstrate that data written by Presto can be read
+using Spark SQL with the Iceberg format, and vice versa.  See

+

+=================
+Iceberg Connector
+=================
+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.
+The Iceberg connector allows querying data stored in
+files written in Iceberg format, as defined in the
+`Iceberg Table Spec <https://iceberg.apache.org/spec/>`_.
+
+The Iceberg connector supports:
+
+* All Presto types, including TIME, TIMESTAMP, DECIMAL
+* CREATE TABLE and CREATE TABLE AS
+* Partitioning tables by any Presto type
+* Dropping tables
+* Renaming tables
+* Deletion by partition
+* Table and column statistics
+* Table and column comments
+* Rolling back a table to a previous state
+* Schema evolution
+
+The Iceberg table state is maintained in metadata files. All changes to table state
+create a new metadata file and replace the old metadata with an atomic swap.
+The table metadata file tracks the table schema, partitioning config,
+custom properties, and snapshots of the table contents.
+
+Iceberg data files can be stored in either Parquet or ORC format, as
+determined by the ``format`` property in the table definition.  The
+table ``format`` defaults to ``ORC``.
+
+Iceberg is designed to improve on the known scalabilty limitations of Hive.  Hive
+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.
+
+Status
+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.
+
+Compatibility With Spark Iceberg
+--------------------------------
+
+Tests have been written to demonstrate that data written by Presto can be read
+using Spark SQL with the Iceberg format, and vice versa.  See

+-------------

+At a minimum, ``hive.metastore.uri`` must be configured:

+``year(ts)``                          The partition value is the integer difference in years between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``month(ts)``                         The partition value is the integer difference in months between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``day(ts)``                           The partition value is the integer difference in days between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``hour(ts)``                          The partition value is a TIMESTAMP rounded down to the nearest hour.
+
+``bucket(x, nbuckets)``               The partition value is an integer hash of ``x``, with a value between 0 and ``nbuckets - 1`` inclusive.

+In this example, the table is partitioned by month and by a hash of the account number::
+
+    CREATE TABLE iceberg.testdb.sample_partitioned (
+        order_date DATE,
+        account_number BIGINT,
+        customer VARCHAR)
+    WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['month(order_date)', 'bucket(account_number, 10)'])
+
+Deletion by Partition
+---------------------
+
+For partitioned tables, the Iceberg connector supports the deletion of entire
+partitions if the WHERE clause specifies an identity transform of a partition
+column.  Given this table definition::
+
+    CREATE TABLE test_partition_deletion (
+        c integer,
+        d double)
+        WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['c'])
+
+This SQL will delete all partitions for which c is 1::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1
+
+The current Iceberg connector is based on Iceberg v1.  Iceberg v2 is not yet
+released.  When v2 is released, it will support row-level deletion and the
+Iceberg connector will be updated to provide row-level deletion.
+
+The Iceberg connector currently supports only deletion by partition.
+This SQL below will fail because the doesn't span entire partitions::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1 AND d > 10
+
+Rolling Back to a Previous Snapshot
+-----------------------------------
+
+Iceberg supports a "snapshot" model of data, where table snapshots are
+identified by an ``long`` snapshot_ids.
+
+The connector provides a system snapshots table for each Iceberg table.  Snapshots are
+identified by BIGINT snapshot ids.  You can find the latest snapshot id for table
+foo by running the following command::
+
+    SELECT snapshot_id FROM 'foo$snapshots' ORDER BY committed_at DESC LIMIT 1
+
+A SQL procedure ``system.rollback_to_snapshot`` allows the caller to roll back
+the state of the table to a previous snapshot id::
+
+    CALL system.rollback_to_snapshot(schema_name, table_name, snapshot_id)
+
+Schema Evolution
+----------------
+
+Iceberg and the Iceberg connector support schema evolution, with safe
+column add, drop, reorder and rename operations, including in nested structures.
+Table partitioning can also be changed and the connector can still
+query data created before the partitioning change.
+
+Migrating Existing Tables
+-------------------------
+
+The connector can read from or write to Hive tables that have been migrated to Iceberg.
+Currently, there is no Presto support to migrate Hive tables to Presto, so you will
+need to use either the Iceberg API or Spark.
+
+System Tables and Columns
+-------------------------
+
+The connector supports ``table$partitions`` as a substitute for Hive's ``SHOW PARTITIONS``.
+The differences are that it returns some partition metrics for each partition value
+and you can also use it on unpartitioned tables.
+
+Iceberg supports ``$snapshot_id`` and ``$snapshot_timestamp_ms`` as hidden columns.
+These columns allow users to query an old version of the table. Think of this
+as a time-travel feature which lets you query your table's snapshot at a given time.
+
+Iceberg Table Properties
+------------------------
+
+================================================== ============================================================ ============
+Property Name                                      Description                                                  Default
+================================================== ============================================================ ============
+``format``                                         Optionally specifies the format of table data files;         ORC
+                                                   either PARQUET or ORC.
+
+``partitioning``                                   Optionally specifies table partitioning.
+                                                   If a table is partitioned by columns c1 and c2, the
+                                                   partitioning property would be
+                                                   ``partitioning = ARRAY['c1', 'c2']``
+
+``location``                                       Optionally specifies the file system location URI for
+                                                   the table
+================================================== ============================================================ ============
+
+The table definition below specifies format PARQUET, partitioning by columns c1 and c2,

+=================
+Iceberg Connector
+=================
+
+Overview
+--------
+
+Apache Iceberg is an open table format for huge analytic datasets.
+The Iceberg connector allows querying data stored in
+files written in Iceberg format, as defined in the
+`Iceberg Table Spec <https://iceberg.apache.org/spec/>`_.
+
+The Iceberg connector supports:
+
+* All Presto types, including TIME, TIMESTAMP, DECIMAL
+* CREATE TABLE and CREATE TABLE AS
+* Partitioning tables by any Presto type
+* Dropping tables
+* Renaming tables
+* Deletion by partition
+* Table and column statistics
+* Table and column comments
+* Rolling back a table to a previous state
+* Schema evolution
+
+The Iceberg table state is maintained in metadata files. All changes to table state
+create a new metadata file and replace the old metadata with an atomic swap.
+The table metadata file tracks the table schema, partitioning config,
+custom properties, and snapshots of the table contents.
+
+Iceberg data files can be stored in either Parquet or ORC format, as
+determined by the ``format`` property in the table definition.  The
+table ``format`` defaults to ``ORC``.
+
+Iceberg is designed to improve on the known scalabilty limitations of Hive.  Hive
+stores table metadata in an object store backed by a database like MySQL.  It tracks
+partition locations in the metastore, but not individual data files.  Presto queries
+using the Hive connector must first call the metastore to get partition locations,
+then call the underlying filesystem to list all data files inside each partition,
+and then read metadata from each data file.
+
+Since Iceberg stores the paths to data files in the metadata files, it
+only consults the underlying file system for files that must be read.
+
+Status
+------
+
+The Iceberg connector is not yet supported for production use.
+
+Compatibility With Spark Iceberg
+--------------------------------
+
+Tests have been written to demonstrate that data written by Presto can be read
+using Spark SQL with the Iceberg format, and vice versa.  See
+`TestSparkCompatibility <https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-product-tests/src/main/java/io/prestosql/tests/iceberg/TestSparkCompatibility.java>`_.
+
+Configuration
+-------------
+
+Iceberg supports the same metastore configuration properties as the Hive connector.
+At a minimum, ``hive.metastore.uri`` must be configured:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    connector.name=iceberg
+    hive.metastore.uri=thrift://localhost:9083
+
+Partitioned Tables
+------------------
+
+Iceberg supports partitioning by specifying transforms over the table columns.
+A partition is created for each unique tuple value produced by the transforms.
+Identity transforms are simply the column name. Other transforms are:
+

+Transform                             Description
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+``year(ts)``                          The partition value is the integer difference in years between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``month(ts)``                         The partition value is the integer difference in months between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``day(ts)``                           The partition value is the integer difference in days between ``ts`` and January 1st. 1970.
+
+``hour(ts)``                          The partition value is a TIMESTAMP rounded down to the nearest hour.
+
+``bucket(x, nbuckets)``               The partition value is an integer hash of ``x``, with a value between 0 and ``nbuckets - 1`` inclusive.
+
+``truncate(s, nchars)``               The partition value is the first ``nchars`` characters of VARCHAR ``s``.
+===================================== ================================================================================================
+
+In this example, the table is partitioned by month and by a hash of the account number::
+
+    CREATE TABLE iceberg.testdb.sample_partitioned (
+        order_date DATE,
+        account_number BIGINT,
+        customer VARCHAR)
+    WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['month(order_date)', 'bucket(account_number, 10)'])
+

+---------------------
+
+For partitioned tables, the Iceberg connector supports the deletion of entire
+partitions if the WHERE clause specifies an identity transform of a partition
+column.  Given this table definition::
+

+        c integer,
+        d double)
+        WITH (partitioning = ARRAY['c'])
+
+This SQL will delete all partitions for which c is 1::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1
+
+The current Iceberg connector is based on Iceberg v1.  Iceberg v2 is not yet
+released.  When v2 is released, it will support row-level deletion and the
+Iceberg connector will be updated to provide row-level deletion.
+
+The Iceberg connector currently supports only deletion by partition.
+This SQL below will fail because the doesn't span entire partitions::
+
+    DELETE FROM test_partition_deletion
+    WHERE c = 1 AND d > 10
+

+-----------------------------------
+

+                                                   partitioning property would be
+                                                   ``partitioning = ARRAY['c1', 'c2']``
+
+``location``                                       Optionally specifies the file system location URI for
+                                                   the table
+================================================== ============================================================ ============
